alert.note: Alert for Benton; Jasper; Lake; Newton; Porter (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Chicago (Northeastern Illinois and Northwestern Indiana)
info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 14 at 4:54AM EST by NWS Chicago
info.description: ...Heavy Rainfall Likely Wednesday Night... Current indications are that widespread significant rainfall is likely Wednesday night. Rainfall totals of 1 to 1.5 inches are expected, especially near and south of a Chicago to LaSalle Peru line including northwest Indiana. Latest analysis from the National Operational Hydrologic Remote Sensing Center suggests that a half inch to locally an inch of snow water equivalent remains locked in snow pack across portions of the Kankakee, Illinois, Vermilion, and Iroquois River basins. An unseasonably warm and moist air mass will likely result in rapid melting of the remaining snow pack Tuesday night into Wednesday. The ground remains frozen across the CWA with frost depths of 8 inches to over a foot across the entire CWA. The frozen ground will likely result in a high percentage of runoff from the melting snow and expected heavy rainfall Wednesday night. If rainfall of the expected magnitude falls, then some flooding of low lying and poor drainage areas is likely Wednesday night into Thursday morning. In addition, the run off will flow into area rivers, many of which are partially to largely ice covered. The unseasonably mild temperatures followed by quickly rising stream flow will lead to an increased the risk of localized break up ice jam flooding. Ice jam flooding can develop very quickly and lead to sudden rises in water levels. Any one living near or with interests in low lying or flood prone areas, including near typical ice jam locations on area rivers, should closely monitor later forecasts and statements from the National Weather Service.
